title: Gleanings in Europe: England by James Fenimore Cooper, and Wyandotte, or The Hutted Knoll: A Tale by James Fenimore Cooper, and The Last of the Mohicans: A Narrative of 1757 by James Fenimore Cooper
abstract: Reviews 273 Gleanings in Europe: England. ByJames Fenimore Cooper. Historical Intro­ duction and Explanatory Notes by Donald A. Ringe and Kenneth W. Staggs. (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1980. xl + 375 pages, illustra­ tions, index, $29.50.) Wyandotte, or The Hutted Knoll: A Tale. By James Fenimore Cooper. His­ torical Introduction by Thomas and Marianne Philbrick. (Albany: State Uni­ versity of New York Press, 1982. xxxiii + 434 pages, illustrations, index, $29.50.) The Last of the Mohicans: A Narrative of 1757. ByJames Fenimore Cooper. Historical Introduction by James Franklin Beard. Text Established, with Explanatory Notes, by James A. Sappenfield and E. N. Feltskog. (Albany: The State University of New York Press, 1983. xlvii + 418 pages, illustrations, index, $29.50.) Three more books in the proposed Cooper Collection have recently been issued by The State University of New York Press. Like the others in the series thus far, they are handsome and well-made. The introductions, however, continue to be written by historians. Are we to assume that Cooper’s books are important only within a chronology? Where is the much-needed literary criticism which should introduce these works? That the books keep being published is good. That they are being trans­ formed into histories is bad, even though those histories are written by the likes of James Franklin Beard. RICHARD C. POULSEN Brigham Young University Dictionary of Literary Biography. Volume 12: American Realists and Natural­ ists. Edited by Donald Pizer and Earl N. Harbert. (Detroit, MI: Gale Re­ search Co., 1982. 486 pages, $75.00.) No, your eyes are not deceiving you, for the tome under consideration does indeed cost $75. One of the new Bruccoli Clark reference volumes, this 11J4" x 9" book is designed for library acquisition and use, and will be espe­ cially helpful for students and all interested “general” readers. Writers of American fiction during the artistically fomenting period between the end of the Civil War and the start of World War I are the subjects of this particular volume. Rich in photographs and manuscript samples, the book is attractively designed, and written by numerous well-recognized authorities in this field. Considering that volumes in this series are meant to be introductory, No. 12 is rather thorough. Major writers, such as Clemens, Wharton, and James, receive really extensive treatment;important writers, such as Glasgow, Chopin, Bierce, and Henry Adams, receive detailed treatment; and a host of minor figures, from Lafcadio Hearn to Brand Whitlock, receive substantial ...
